column4: hi - my router's ap cannot be seen by linux. The router is a 802.11n draft 2.0 standard.
does it see the AP's network? if so, then everything is working
> it can see other ap's - but not mine. And windows can see it, so it works.,...
when you say AP i'm thinking of a large wireless network is many AP's and all connect you to one network, if this the case?
well I live in a house with many wifis
so the wireless drivers work, but why can't I see my own router's ap?
ok a router and AP is not the same thing. if it's just a home wireless network it's probably just a router
in the house we have some 10-13 apÃ¸s
>> yes, it can be seen by (sorry) windows
Windows will see if forever after it is known, if you check the router config page, make sure it is broadcasting
>> well, it is broadcasting, but linux cannot see it
how are you coming to the conclusion it is broadcasting? just saying windows see it doesn't tell me anything. windows will see it after you tell it to look for it, it's almost like bluetooth pairing
well, I can see the ap broadcast via windows - so linux ought to be able to do the same
not if it isn't broadcasting. can you please check the router/ap config page?
